TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr Tamer ORG , a lawyer practising in PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant , a professor in chemistry in GPE , was married to a NORP citizen . The wife left GPE for GPE and began divorce proceedings . The applicant found out in DATE that the divorce proceedings had ended but his ex - wife refused , despite the applicant ’s numerous requests , to send him a copy of the divorce decree .

The applicant went to GPE in DATE to see his children who were living with their mother , who had since begun to work as an interpreter for the police . When the applicant found out that his ex - wife was on holiday , he entered the house , using his key , in order to find the divorce decree . The neighbours alerted the police and the applicant was arrested . Following the intervention of the father of his ex - wife , the applicant was released .

The applicant ’s ex - wife later claimed that she found CARDINAL small bottles of liquid in her house . These were handed to the police and were sent for forensic examination on DATE . According to the forensic report , the first bottle contained hydrogen fluoride which was deemed to be exceptionally corrosive and likely to cause severe and disfiguring burns if applied to the skin . The second and the third bottles each contained QUANTITY of cadmium nitrate and nitrate of mercury , both of which were deemed to be heavy metal salts which would cause acute poisoning if ingested in any significant amount . The forensic scientist also stated that these exhibits were dangerous and it would not be safe to submit them for fingerprint analysis .
On DATE the applicant and his new wife went to GPE to visit the applicant ’s children . The applicant was arrested at the airport and was transferred to a police station in GPE .

On DATE the applicant was questioned at GPE police station in relation to the accusations that on DATE he had entered , as a trespasser , his ex - wife ’s house with intent to inflict grievous bodily harm upon his ex - wife by leaving the CARDINAL tubes of chemical corrosives in the house . According to the record of the interview , a legal representative was present during this interview .

It appears from a document submitted by the applicant that on DATE the applicant appeared before ORG . The charges were read out to him but he did not reply . He was charged under LAW of the Offences Against LAW DATE and was remanded in custody .

In DATE the applicant sent a letter to his ex - wife ’s sister , asking her to persuade her sister to withdraw the complaints . This letter was handed to the police by his ex - wife ’s new husband and another charge , namely an “ intention to pervert the course of justice ” , was brought against the applicant .

On DATE , the items found in the applicant ’s ex - wife ’s house were submitted by the police to a forensic scientist for examination , who , in his report of CARDINAL DATE , largely confirmed the earlier forensic findings .

According to the documents , CARDINAL preliminary hearings took place on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and finally on DATE . The applicant ’s application for bail was refused on DATE . During these hearings the applicant was represented by a solicitor and different counsel in each of the hearings , instructed by the solicitor .

The applicant states that these lawyers claimed to have made an agreement with the judge to get a shorter sentence and they attempted to persuade him to accept the charges . He , however , did not accept their suggestions . When the applicant sought an independent forensic expertise , he learnt that the bottles and their contents had been destroyed . The independent forensic scientist prepared a report on the basis of the CARDINAL earlier reports .

On DATE a hearing took place at ORG in GPE . According to the applicant the hearing lasted TIME . At the end of the trial the applicant was acquitted of the charges against him and he was released DATE . The applicant left GPE on DATE . He further claims that a copy of the judgment was never communicated to him .

The applicant , who contacted his solicitor in GPE from GPE and told her that he wished to bring a claim for compensation against the authorities in GPE , was informed by the solicitor that the fee would be £ MONEY .

The applicant also claims that he contacted CARDINAL other lawyers in GPE , CARDINAL of whom never replied and the other advised him that he could bring an action in GPE via FAC in GPE and without leaving GPE . When he contacted ORG in GPE he was told that this was not possible .

The applicant contacted ORG again , this time for a visa in order to go to GPE to start the proceedings . He was told to bring all the documents relating to his case in GPE and was given an appointment for DATE .

On DATE the applicant and his wife went to FAC in GPE . The applicant had in his possession CARDINAL small bottles containing potassium nitrate as well as the documents relating to his trial in GPE . The applicant showed these bottles to the NORP employee and stated that it was because of bottles similar to these that he had spent DATE in prison in GPE . He claimed that they were completely harmless and that he could even consume them . The ORG employee contacted the police who arrested the applicant and his wife and released them later . This incident was widely reported in the national media .

The applicant had CARDINAL subsequent appointments at FAC in GPE , during which he asked for assistance to initiate a court action in GPE . He was told that he would be informed when they had obtained information from GPE .

The applicant , after having received the forensic report in relation to the CARDINAL bottles for which he was arrested in GPE , brought an action against FAC in GPE . He claimed that , as established by forensic examination , the contents of the bottles were completely harmless and that the Consulate ’s actions resulted in him being branded as a “ terrorist ” by the media . The case was rejected by ORG of First Instance on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to try the actions of another ORG . The subsequent appeal against this judgment was also rejected by ORG on DATE .

On DATE the applicant received a letter from FAC in GPE , stating that his application for a visa was refused on the ground that “ the initial enquiries as to the feasibility of an action to sue the Police and ORG could easily be made from GPE ” . The letter further stated that in the light of the previous charges brought against him in GPE , “ his exclusion from GPE was conducive to the public good ” .
